tobj.parser¶

The TinyObj Parser

This module defines the Abstract Syntax Tree (AST) nodes and the Parser class responsible for consuming tokens produced by the Lexer and constructing the AST.

Classes¶

ASTNode

Base class for all AST nodes.

ObjectNode

Represents an object declaration: *ObjectName.

PropertyNode

Represents a property assignment: >key value or >key followed by a list.

Parser

The TinyObj Parser.

Functions¶

main()

Example usage of the Lexer and Parser to demonstrate AST construction.

Module Contents¶

class tobj.parser.ASTNode(pos_start: tobj.errors.Position, pos_end: tobj.errors.Position)[source]¶

Base class for all AST nodes.

Parameters:

  • pos_start (Position) – The starting position in the source code.

  • pos_end (Position) – The ending position in the source code.

Bases: ASTNode

Represents a property assignment: >key value or >key followed by a list.

Parameters:

  • value (Any) – The Python value assigned to the property (str, int, float, bool, None, or List).

class tobj.parser.Parser(tokens: List[tobj.lexer.Token])[source]¶

The TinyObj Parser.

Consumes a stream of tokens and builds a list of ASTNode objects (ObjectNode and PropertyNode).

Parameters:

tokens (List[Token]) – The input list of tokens from the Lexer.

Variables:

  • pos (int) – The current index in the token list.

  • current_token (Optional[Token]) – The token currently being processed.

tokens: List[tobj.lexer.Token][source]¶
pos: int = 0[source]¶
current_token: tobj.lexer.Token | None[source]¶
advance() → None[source]¶

Move the parser position to the next token.

peek(offset: int = 1) → tobj.lexer.Token | None[source]¶

Look ahead at a future token without advancing the position.

Parameters:

offset (int) – Number of tokens to look ahead. Defaults to 1.

Returns:

The token at the peeked position, or None if past EOF.

Return type:

Optional[Token]

expect(token_type: str) → tobj.lexer.Token[source]¶

Consume a token of the expected type.

If the current token matches the expected type, it is consumed and returned. Otherwise, a ParserError is raised.

Parameters:

token_type (str) – The expected type of the token.

Returns:

The consumed token.

Return type:

Token

Raises:

ParserError – If the token type does not match or if EOF is reached unexpectedly.

skip_newlines() → None[source]¶

Consume and discard all contiguous NEWLINE tokens.

token_to_value(token: tobj.lexer.Token)[source]¶

Convert a value token (STRING, NUMBER, BOOLEAN, NOTHING) into its corresponding Python value.

Parameters:

token (Token) – The token to convert.

Returns:

The Python representation of the token’s value.

Return type:

Any

Raises:

ParserError – If the token type is not a valid value type.

parse_object() → ObjectNode[source]¶

Parses an object declaration: *ObjectName.

Returns:

The constructed AST node.

Return type:

ObjectNode

parse_list_items() → Tuple[List, tobj.errors.Position][source]¶

Parses list items following a property key (handles both one-line and multi-line lists).

Returns:

A tuple containing the list of parsed values and the position of the last parsed item’s end.

Return type:

Tuple[List, Position]

parse_property() → PropertyNode[source]¶

Parses a property assignment: >key value, >key, or >key followed by a list.

Returns:

The constructed AST node.

Return type:

PropertyNode

Raises:

ParserError – If a keyword is used as a key, or an unexpected token is found.

parse() → List[ASTNode][source]¶

Main parsing method.

Iterates through the tokens and dispatches to object or property parsing methods.

Returns:

The complete Abstract Syntax Tree, represented as a list of top-level nodes.

Return type:

List[ASTNode]

Raises:

ParserError – If an unexpected token is encountered outside of a valid structure.

Example usage of the Lexer and Parser to demonstrate AST construction.
